												-- THIS IS NOT A FANBOY REVIEW -- So I'm going to lists some pros and cons so far into my gaming experience.PROS:+Japanese import cars+PS4 remote compatible( I use Pinnacle Game Profiler ) +The turbo spools+Some drift tracks are okay+The aftermarket parts are cheap+It's easy to make money just by drifting+They have a Toyota Chaser dammit, other game industries should learn from this+Interior is not bad at all, just need minor touching here and there+When in interior mode the driver moves his head left and right when in drift mode and is not stiff.+You can adjust the camber and offset of your car+Music is alright, the list should be more at least but it has potential.+They have mods which is nice ( My favs: Ebisu, Tsukuba etc )+Community is good+Dat price thoCONS:-The car lists can should be more considering some of these cars aren't even licensed. -You hit a wall and your car goes flying in the air like it's zero gravity. -You hit a wall slightly (like a small wall tap) and all of your points is gone.-I don't know what's up with the recent update but the frames are like 14fps on max settings-Some of the cars sound like vacuum cleaner which should be polished a tad bit or at least mess aroundwith the sound editing ( Not the 1JZ it sounds great )-The tracks should be polished a bit as well, there's some invisible walls sticking out on Drift Track 1-There's hackers which needs to be dealt with seriously.-No customization parts for the exterior or interior of the car or able to remove front bumper to expose intercooler.-No neons or strobes which is a bit sad honestly-No in-game vinyls such as itasha, tribal, real life car designs etc-No workshop for this game...like how can you not.-Can barely do a tandem or drift train with somebody without their car lagging back towards you causing it to hit you and then you lose all of your points and everyone elses.-No steam trading cards or achievementsThat's about it honestly. I somewhat recommend this game but it does need a polish on a few areas listed above since there's too many fanboysoverhyping this game. 												I'd recommend this, ONLY if the following apply to you.-You got a few bucks burning a hole in your pocket-You have access to a decent steering wheel (Logitech or better)-And are willing to put some work into sorting your controls (both via wheel & in-game)Things like visuals & audio are always subjective, some might like it, some won't. Music volume can be controlled if you don't like it, engine/exhaust/tire sounds do their part well, and the visuals are a step-above the old NFS-Underground games.If you're looking to play with a controller, wait until full-support is confirmed, or don't bother as it won't work.(long story short, it's both game & controller related, involving trigger command-axis issues)That^ said, I have been enjoying the game with my Logitech G27, set-up to behave like a drifting go-kart of sorts. The game offers some level of 'customization', which devolves to body-color/wheel color combos, and what engine/perfomance-stage parts you choose. There are a fair amount of JDM cars to choose from, and PLENTY of engine-swap choices (my current/favorite combo is a "S240" [a.k.a 240sx] with a ~500hp KA24DE[-T] motor).The physics are arcade-ish, but feel more 'weighed-down' than the NFS2015 "200mph EVERYWHERE" behavior, think the old Underground games with a hint-more realism and weight.Is there $7-worth of content ? - debatable Is there $7-worth of entertainment in the game ? - I'd say yes;Between the solo-mode and the lag-chaos of online, the occasional online tandem (that doesn't end in cars getting launched to space - although still humorous) and the solo practice of finding the sweet-spot for your driving style and the cars perfomance, I could see anyone (who's done the research/effort and didn't just go "GAME BROKE PLZ FIX) enjoying themselves for around 7-hours total.

												A quick summary: this is a very rudimentary release about a year of two of development away from being an actual game, and the store page hugely exaggerates the features on offer.Driving: Initially in the only available starter car, the physics seem decent with a fairly natural if exaggerated feel to the drifting. However, as soon as you add power or change to another car it starts to fall apart, with bizarre spins, slides and acceleration in unexpected directions. It feels more like a set of predefined reactions to certain inputs rather than any actual physics simulation, and once you deviate from basic powerslides it breaks.Graphics: The car models are serviceable if rather low-poly (ignoring the large holes in some), but the tracks are very, very basic - some games of the 1990s had more trackside detail. The 'traffic' only exists on one track, and seems to be mainly static cars with extremely low levels of detail.Gameplay: The only gameplay loop that exists is that scoring drift points gives the player a small amount of money per point, which they can use to upgrade then score more points. There is no other gameplay at all.UI: The menus are relatively clean and functional, however simply viewing any performance upgrade seems to immediately purchase it with no confirmation.Audio: The sound effects are passable, the highlight being the turbo sounds. The music is not to my own tastes, but the production is at least okay.Car culture: The choice of cars is well selected for a drifting game. While bodykits are only currently implemented for one car, and there are only 5 choices of wheels, the sheer presence of visual upgrades at least scores a point here. The engine swapping feature is also decent, although the stats for the engines generally bear very little resemblance to the real engines that they are named after.Overall: The game frankly lacks even the most basic levels of polish or even gameplay, and has some jarring inconsistencies in the quality of the art assets. While the developers clearly have put some heart into it and are continuing to work on the game, I wouldn't recommend a purchase now unless it's 90% off and you're happy with 20 minutes or so of just toying around. Hopefully the support keeps coming, and in a year or two this may be worth the budget price.

												I have been playing this game for a few hours now, enough to which I feel I can review the game in it's current state.The game overall is very enjoyable to hop on and do some solo drifting or some online tandems. There is a decent amount of cars to choose from as you progress and gain more money (Unless you know how to use regedit xD). The customisation is not amazing nor awful, it is in the middle. There are body mods unique to most cars, be warned some cars currently have no body mods! The engine swaps are an awesome feature that do change the cars overall feeling but the engine tuning is pretty poor in the sense that it is all the same but then again there is not a lot that can change from car to car. The maps are all great in my opinion and the map creator feature is a great addition to try out for all players! The map creator currently does not have lots of objects but there is enough to play around with. The game does not feel near to finished but is constantly being developed.The bad point for many players is the controller issue. For myself this is no problem as I own a G25, but the controller input is complete garbage and is not even worth trying! Using a keyboard also sucks so don't expect much without a wheel!!! But let's be real here for £3.99 you cannot get a better drifting game!Overall I enjoy the game and can't wait to see new features being added in the future!

												Love Cars? Drifting? Illegal races?  This is your game!I love this game, I lovespeed and cars. I remember when after school I went to arcades to play the classic Daytona with my friends. This is not "Daytona" but a nice version of an illegal racing, in your illegal garage with the chance of putting some stuff in your car.This is a really good game with a lot of options a the garage to set up your engines, cambers, offsets, and, of course, all tunning stuff related! Of course, takes money from your budget. At the beginning, you have to start with a base car. The good news: painting it's free! Then with the money you will be able to change the engine, adding extra HP it's quite nice. Don't forget to check the turbo, adding nitro and many other interesting things. Of course, we can change the body, swap, and rims!Gameplay: I suggest a joystick, but also keyboard helps. You have the LAN option, playing alone or with friends at the Japan highways or multiplayer version, with other people and try to get some money. You have a chat option and summon friends to race or just having fun drifting. You have a lot of things to do.You have two cameras options, third person, and first person, I always like third but both are great.Graphics: Graphics are not bad. We are not talking about GTA V but I really like the work of the artist team. Cars are different, you can personalize colors. Textures are cool too.Music: The best part of it. The sound of the engine is different from first person camera, also the music. And the themes are just great. Enjoy good music for speed? You gonna have it here!Creating new scenarios: I think this is the big one of the game. You can create your own racetrack! I tried, but I have to say you need patience. The editor seems not to be complicated but you need to have some time.Extras: There's no presentation of the game after the "made by unity". You just go to the garage. I suggest to fix that, would be nice to have a good presentation of the game.You can subscribe the forum. You'll get an extra car if you validate your Steam account. Also, many gamers share their scenarios created with the editor and you can download them for free! It's a great community. I loved that.All extras of this games deserve a 3/5. Of course, all games could be better but this one, I loved it.Suit up boys and girls, it's time for speed!

												Dont know what to write here so here is how to install a turbo boost gauge.A little bit of consideration is essential before handing over your cash for a particular boost gauge.First, you need to decide the maximum boost pressure you plan to run. If, for example, you expect to run no more than 1.2 Bar (17.4 psi), a gauge that reads up to 1.5 Bar (21.8 psi) is perfect - it's good to have a little bit of headroom so you can recognise overboost conditions.You may be aware that some boost gauges read positive pressure and engine vacuum; a vacuum scale is very handy for setting up an adjustable blow-off valve, general tuning and faultfinding. Speaking from experience, it's also the easiest way to identify when a small hose has popped off the intake manifold. Certainly, where possible, go for a boost gauge that shows vacuum.Note that the sweep of the needle is important for viewing accuracy - the greater the sweep, the more likely you'll make a correct reading. Another important factor is the diameter of the gauge - the most common diameter is 52mm, but smaller 40mm units can also be bought. Unless mounting space is an issue (which you'll need to determine before making a purchase) we'd opt for the larger size gauge, as they're considerably easier to read.And what's better - a metric or imperial boost gauge? This comes down mainly to personal preference. Psi (pounds per square inch), kilopascals (kPa) and Bar are the most common pressure units - whichever of these suits you is fine.Your budget will determine whether you'll be using a mechanical or, possibly, an electronic boost gauge. Mechanical boost gauges, which use an internal Bourdin tube, can be bought brand new from as little as $40. Electronic boost gauges, however, can run to several hundred dollars. As the name implies, an electronic boost gauge is fed an electrical signal from a remote pressure sensor. Electronic boost gauges have a few advantages - they generally have slightly better accuracy, most have a peak recall function and, because the gauge is fed an electric signal from a remote pressure sensor, there's no requirement to run an air hose into the cabin.Installing a Mechanical Boost GaugeWhere to Find the Optimal Pressure SourceThe best spot to connect a boost gauge is the intake manifold; most typically by 'T-ing' into one of the existing manifold hoses. So why is the intake manifold best, you ask?First, manifold vacuum won't register on boost/vacuum gauges unless you make a connection downstream of the throttle body (ie inside the intake manifold). Only boost pressure can be measured along the path between the turbocharger and throttle body.The second advantage of connecting the boost gauge to the intake manifold is you'll receive a more accurate representation of actual boost - the amount of positive pressure received by the engine. Connecting a boost gauge anywhere between the turbo compressor and throttle will give a too-high boost reading. Thanks to the inevitable restriction through the intercooler core, intercooler plumbing and throttle body, an engine suffers a boost pressure loss on-route to the manifold.Click for larger image Using a 1994 Subaru Impreza WRX as a demo, we T'd our boost gauge (a second-hand Japanese import job) into one of the hose connections on the topside of the manifold. The hose we selected was one that connects to the purge control solenoid on the underside of the manifold.Note that - instead of cutting the factory solenoid hose - we fitted a T-piece to the existing end and added another short length of hose to hook onto the manifold connection. This means, if we later decide to remove the boost gauge, the original hose will be long enough to reattach to the manifold connection. The third port of the T-piece is dedicated to the boost gauge.And what sort of T-pieces should be used? Brass fittings are certainly the most durable but for a completely stealth installation you can't go past the plastic T-pieces used on 993cc Daihatsu Charade carby turbo engines. We're led to believe that the same T-pieces are fitted to atmo versions as well. These beaut little T-pieces can be picked up from the wreckers for free!To ensure none of your boost gauge hoses pop apart, the vacuum hose clamps used on the Daihatsu Charade Turbo are, again, ideal and available for free. We didn't bother with these since we don't expect to run mega boost.Four millimetre rubber vacuum hose - available from auto parts stores for around $3 per metre - is fine for running from the manifold to the in-cabin gauge. Vacuum hose offers OE-level durability and it integrates into the underbonnet scenery perfectly.Routing the HoseThere are a couple of things to remember when routing the hose from the manifold to the in-cabin gauge. The hose should not be kinked, it should be kept well away from intense heat sources and it should not foul the operation of any moving parts - particularly the throttle!We routed our boost gauge hose around the factory blow-off valve tube, beneath the top-mount intercooler, parallel with some factory tubes that run along the firewall and, finally, though the firewall. A couple of cable ties were used to secure the hose into position.Most cars have several firewall openings that are capped with a rubber or plastic seal; we'll use one of these to pass through our boost hose. Have a good look under the bonnet to find a seal that isn't too crowded with wires and/or cables and prise it away from the firewall using a flat-blade screwdriver - be careful not to strain any wires or cables from inside the car. Next, enlarge the hole in the seal so it's big enough to accept the 4mm rubber hose - this can be done with a pair of pointed scissors or a razor. With that done, refit the seal to the firewall and poke the boost hose through to the cabin.Note - in no circumstance should a hose, cable or electrical wire rub against the metal edge of the firewall hole. Install a firewall seal from another vehicle or use a sheath (even just a short length of rubber hose) to avoid contact with that sharp metal edge.Working from the driver's foot well, route the hose beneath the dashboard so it won't foul the operation of the pedals, steering, handbrake or any other controls. Again, use cable ties to secure the hose at various locations to prevent it falling somewhere it shouldn't - like on your feet while driving! Cut the hose in the vicinity where you intend to mount the gauge.Most boost gauges incorporate a bulb for nighttime illumination. Two electrical terminals can usually be found on the back of the gauge - one for a positive electrical feed and one for Earth. Note that - unless LEDs are used for illumination rather than a conventional bulb - you can hook either terminal to the positive or Earth wire. A conventional bulb is not polarity conscious.So where should you wire the illumination bulb to? Well, the best place is to connect into the existing instrument illumination circuit - this enables the boost gauge to illuminate along with the rest of the vehicle's instruments.In the case of this particular install, we powered the boost gauge bulb from the illumination circuit for the cigarette lighter (which is immediately alongside). We simply T'd into the two wires that are used to illuminate the cigarette lighter surround and ran the appropriate length of hook-up wire to the ashtray area. To enable easy installation and future removal, we soldered two short lengths of wire onto the gauge terminals and adjoined the ends with a pair of spade connectors.Note that most (all?) cars' electrical systems will be able to cope with an extra bulb without being overloaded.
